chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Suspected acute stroke
chapter.summary: Covers the management in primary care of people who present with symptoms suggestive of an acute stroke. Because transient ischaemic attack (TIA) cannot be confidently diagnosed unless the symptoms have resolved within 24 hours, people with ongoing neurological symptoms and signs suggestive of acute stroke or TIA should be treated as if they have stroke.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with suspected acute stroke?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Arrange immediate emergency admission to an acute stroke facility for anyone with:
    • Persisting neurological symptoms suspected of having acute stroke or emergent TIA.
    • Resolved neurological symptoms who has a bleeding disorder or is taking an anticoagulant — haemorrhage must be excluded.
  • Be aware that a person may have ongoing focal neurological deficits despite a negative FAST test — if suspected manage as acute stroke.
  • Ensure that ambulance control understands the urgency of the situation and that the person needs to be taken immediately to the nearest hospital with facilities for stroke thrombolysis.
  • Inform the hospital in advance of arrival — include details of time of onset, symptom evolution, current condition and medications (especially anticoagulants).
  • Do not start antiplatelet treatment until haemorrhagic stroke has been ruled out by a brain scan.
  • While awaiting transfer:
    • Monitor and manage any deterioration in clinical condition (airway, breathing and circulation [ABCs]).
    • Give supplemental oxygen to people with acute stroke if oxygen saturations are less than 95% and there are no contraindications.
  • Admission may not be appropriate/beneficial in a small number of people with a severe comorbidity. If after discussion with the person and their family/carer, a decision is made not to admit:
    • Clearly document the reasons for this and,
    • Discuss with the specialist team possible assessment and management at home or as an out-patient within 24 hours.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on when to admit a person with suspected stroke or TIA are based on the clinical guidelines Guidelines for the early management of patients with acute ischemic stroke: a guideline for healthcare professionals from the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association [Jauch, 2013], Stroke and transient ischemic attack: acute and long term management [British Columbia Medical Association, 2015] and National clinical guideline for stroke (Prepared by the Intercollegiate Stroke Working Party) [RCP, 2016] and expert opinion in a review article [Wein, 2015].

Stroke and emergent transient ischaemic attack (TIA) are medical emergencies — emergency admission for urgent assessment by a specialist is needed to differentiate between acute stroke and other causes of symptoms [British Columbia Medical Association, 2015; RCP, 2016].

  • Rapid assessment and treatment are essential in reduction of stroke related disability and mortality [British Columbia Medical Association, 2015].
  • The recommended maximum time between admission and brain imaging has been reduced by the Intercollegiate Working Party from 12 hours to ‘urgently and at most within 1 hour of arrival at hospital’ to maximise the potential benefit from revascularization treatments and management of intracerebral haemorrhage [RCP, 2016].
  • A Cochrane review found that people with stroke treated as in-patients on a stroke unit are more likely to survive and be living at home independently one year after onset [Stroke Unit Trialists' Collaboration, 2013].
Notify hospital of possible stroke and handover appropriately
  • Several studies have shown that advance notification of arrival reduces time to specialist assessment and imaging, and is associated with higher rates of intravenous recombinant tissue-type plasminogen activator [Jauch, 2013; Wein, 2015].
Withhold antiplatelet therapy until haemorrhagic stroke has been excluded
  • The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) and Royal College of Physicians guidelines recommend that a brain scan be used to rule out haemorrhagic stroke because antiplatelet therapy increases the risk of intracranial haemorrhage following haemorrhagic stroke [National Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions, 2008; RCP, 2016].
